reviews.review_msg: Try to do well on the lab assignments, even if the TA is not very nice/helpful. It will you you good in the end. Participation is also important. Prof mostly reads off slides. Ask questions if you don't understand. Midterm was cool, but the cumulative final, imo, was bad. Felt like I studied alota stuff not on the exam. Idk maybe it's just me...

Very bad prof. Speed up everything and you can hardly catch the information. Too many unrelated material used. Does not have a actual review session. You would feel disrespected during the whole course. Grade by only several points.
disorganized and frequently behind

If this class is not necessary for you to take, I recommend avoiding it at all costs. Nick is a nice person who is very passionate about the material but his disorganization and lack of communication ruins the course experience completely. Assignment criteria is very unclear, and anything NOT graded by the TA will take forever to be graded.

I found his lectures incredibly difficult to follow. He moved quite quickly with little explanation and did not provide the basic understanding before moving onto harder topics. The criteria sheet for the assignments are all over the place and is not well laid out. It took over 6 weeks for 50% of the class to receive their midterm grades.

Nick is a great guy, but his disorganization is what ruins his classes for me. Due dates on canvas don't match with the syllabus almost ever. Canvas modules is always a mess and videos aren't named in the same format.

Nice and interesting guy. Lectures weren't always on topic and he often spoke about his own projects, which was interesting at times but not after the 2nd or 3rd time. As a prof he was fine, my issue is just with the course design.

Great prof! while he wasn't really responsible for the marking, that was all on the TA. Very engaging and captures your attention with the lectures and plenty of real world examples. He does talk a lot about his own work but that didn't really bug me. Overall great prof really enjoyed the course.

Nice and funny guy. Passionate about his course. Doesn't use Canvas so you have to search your email every time for lec notes. Sometimes he doesn't even send lec notes. He tests literally every slide in his lectures and be prepared to write in font size 6 cuz he gives no space. And I've only received 1 response from the 4 questions I emailed him.

nick is a super nice person who genuinely cares about his students, prepare to work hard, but the work was worth it. you leave his class feeling like you really learned and can apply what he is teaching in future courses or even jobs. the only annoying thing is that he doesn't use canvas, so you have to sift through your email for everything

Nick is a nice guy, but his lectures are very dry. He always starts a few minutes early, gives no break (2hr lecture) and then goes a few minutes past the end every week. He is also very disorganized. He doesn't use Canvas, and he often forgets to send out lecture notes after class. The labs are a HUGE headache too. Would not recommend this class.

Nick is a good guy but his midterm was extremely hard. There is a textbook for the course but just rely on the lecture slides. The labs were pretty intense as well, had to work on projects outside of lab time in the computer lab because it was sort of hard. He made the final a little bit easier. And the final project will take forever to complete

Geog 255 with Nick was one of the most difficult courses I've taken at SFU, but now that it's done, I genuinely feel like I understand ArcGIS as a tool. Labs are difficult and time-consuming, but with help from the TA, it was manageable. Overall, very happy with the outcome and I will definitely be using the information again in the future.

Nick has a passion for GIS, and he enjoys sharing his work within the GIS field. Nick's intention is to equip everyone with the capability of not only knowing how to work the software, but being able to apply everyday concepts in to creating logical maps that represent the complexity of our world. His class is hard, but its very much worth it!!

Nick is a great prof who is very passionate about his topic. He tends to get off topic and lectures and slides are sometimes a bit hard to follow. His labs and final project also requires a lot of time and effort. Overall an engaging teacher who is eager to help his students succeed!

This was supposed to be an introductory class, but I felt lost from the first lecture onwards. He didn't give breaks and lectures were extremely hard to follow. Labs took hours and the program you use crashes and stops working all the time. He doesn't use canvas and sends lectures infrequently. Lab slides lacked a lot of crucial information as well
Seems like a good guy but expects a lot from his students. He is very passionate about his field and may go a little overboard. Tests are fair.

Nick has such high interest and knowledge in this subject that sometimes he happens to overlook the fact that he is teaching a 200 level introductory course. He has high expectations for quality projects and papers. Lectures were 2 hours long without any breaks and extremely boring to sit through. Lecture content was unorganized but tests were fair

His lecture slides are not very clear, not organized, filled with picture . tests are not fair, he is British so the way he writes questions is kind of puzzling. He is nice guy but does not mean a great professor. I feel bad because I studied hard but did not do well. The lab teacher is very helpful.

Midterm/exam was fair. Study the review and the lecture slides. Don't need to read textbook. Start project early so you can study for exam. Project was hard - he expects very high quality professional work. Labs weren't so bad because the TA was so helpful and told us exactly what to do. Memorize all the definitions on slides and graphics.

Nick is a FANTASTIC teacher! He is extremely knowledgeable and really wants his students to learn and grow as GIScientists. Don't take this course if you want an easy A, you will have to work hard, but it is rewarding. Many students have gotten jobs by bringing their final projects from this course to job interviews. BEST professor I've ever had.

Quite a hard instructor for a 200 level (heard 300+ level is much harder). Lots of words you have to memorize, he always uses big words and looks for "quality" industry like projects, but in the end if you do a reasonable job you will get a good grade. Pretty stressful tho. In the end everything required was fair. But stressful :)

He urged us to get started on projects, but didn't give the assignment til many weeks into term. Then the guidelines were TMI without much focus. The GIS instruction was almost useless, very inadequate. The worst "practical" instruction I have had at SFU. It could have been so simple and clear for our first intro to GIS.

He's a pretty good prof, but exams are pretty tough, lots of definitions. Just memorize the lecture slides, and go to the TA's office hours and you'll be fine. Start your project wayyyy early if you can, it gets very hectic in the labs.

Nick is a great professor at the top of his field.  He is extremely helpful with the final project if you see him in office hours.  Do NOT take this class if you're looking to just breeze through it, as he works you extremely hard.  The TA, Sonja, was amazing.

I loved Nick! He's a wonderful professor. He speaks to students as equals, is extremely helpful, and very interested in what he teaches. He chatted with me several times, even on passing in the hallway, to ask what I thought of the class, the assignments, ect. The TA (Matt) was incredibley unhelpful though.

Nick's very friendly and willing to help; he loves it when people go to his office hours and he's got lots of interesting tidbits of knowledge. The midterm was fairly straightforward; memorize terms and be able to fill in the blanks. The TA was not very helpful.

Nick is a great guy and cutting-edge in his field.  He's an honest-to-god guy working in the field, and it shows in his class.  He is so willing to help out students, and he wants to see you succeed.  TA Cyrille was AWESOME.

Great Class! If you are willing to put effort into this class you will see it reflected in your grade.Prof more than happy to meet with students to help them with the course and the project, I felt the prof and TA gave up a lot more of their time to students than expected of them. Tests were fair - easy if you studied off the lecture slides.

I don't understand why this guy is allowed to teach.  Very arrogant and self-centered person with no respect towards his students.  He must have some kind of inferiority complex or something.  His lectures are unclear and leaves you even more confused on some things.  I hope he gets fired cause they need to find better profs then this loser.

Lectures are just a stream of jargon. Focuses on theoretical frameworks, but fails to actually make a point because lectures are so disorganized. Labs are ridiculous with most of the marks coming from basic questions that involve searching for definitions of phrases from lectures notes. If you have a good TA the labs themselves aren't bad.
easy class, interesting teacher

Ah, Nick. Where to begin? He's definately arrogant, but his exams weren't that hard if you memorized all his slides. . .the labs seem easy, but if the TA's in a bad mood, you'll see it in your mark. I don't blame them though, I'd be in bad mood too if Nick was my supervisor . . .

This class should come with a warning label attatched. The project can be disasterous if you do not spend the last 2 weeks of your life dedicated towards it (which I did!) The exams aren't nearly as bad, just have to memorize each and every of the 1000 slides! Walked away with a pretty good grade but was defenitely the hardest class I've ever taken

Nick's a brilliant guy but not much of a teacher. Still, he'll do his best to help you if you see him in office hours. Overall, the course was actually quite easy. The exams were simple (if you can memorize 500 slides) and there were many easy bonus questions (about 15% of the exams were bonus questions!). The project is too time consuming tho!

He's not that bad. Focus on the labs, they'll help on the final project (the hardest component of 255). His review sheet is a dead give-away for what's on the exam. He repeats a lot of lecture slides so pay attention to those.

i was really excited about this course...before i took it!!!!  Lecture material is very abstract, disorganized and confusing.  Labs were terrible and ignored by the prof and it really depended how good your TA was or how much time you had to teach yourself. i was completely lost in this course. i would not recommend it to anyone. there really needs

A disorganized and heavy memorization course! I could have bought the text and ESRI manual and learnt the same things, and save myself hard earned tuition $$!! Will never take any courses with this Prof. again. His arrogant attitude to students sucks.

I disagree. I found the class very informative.Then again I was interested in GIS when I enrolled. Teaching, he takes the course material very seriously but is super nice and willing to help if you go to office hours. There was a lot of content, but he gives out tons of prep materials for the midterm and final so if you study you should do well

Was the worst taught course that I have EVER taken.  Disorganized, boring, dry, expects memorization of details not theories.  Hypocritical - his typos are okay, students are not.  Does not respond to emails.  Grades on a massive curve.  I hated everything about this course.  Take G250/1 instead or with a different prof.
Where do they get these profs from?? Boring class, self-centered person, and click-button labs. I regret taking this class as I learnt nothing and paid a lot of fees for these credits.

Final Exam average is extremely lower than Midterm average. Final exam is super hard. If you have 97% on midterm, don't worry you will have 52% on the final. Is that great? He aspected to memorize all his disorganized lectures. His exams are extremely hard.  The lab is fine and just follows the steps.  You will be okay.
This class really really sucks in every way!!  I can't even explain how bad this course is, just speechless...
If you dont have to take this class dont!! The lectures are disorganized and the labs are super hard; making things worse, the TA's are no help at all!!

Disorganized prof. Midterm was not a thinking exam, but more of a memorizing one. TA's are pretty useless cuz they themselves don't know the program. His lectures are not too boring, he tries to be interesting. He is so picky about spelling mistakes on assignments.  Just read his assignments, he aint perfect in spelling and grammar...

He is a super nice prof.  He tried to do something for the students and he is the only prof in SFU that I've ever came in contact with that is willing to do so.  Totally recommend taking a class with him.  Even thou TAs are not helpful, he's super nice and approachable.   Plus he is super hot.

Oh My.  Be prepared to spend a lot of time in the lab.  His tests are really really hard and the TA's are not very helpful! I would suggest takiing this class with the other prof, which I think is Sherman.

He's sometimes scattered in lectures. He use to have technical difficulties with AV eq. He's very interested in what he teaches... I wish he would organize his slides better. He does put fun pictures as part of his slides. He surfs, he's British, he's kinda hot for a geog prof.. not bad to look at.
Her marking and her t.a's marking are tough, but she gives a good lecture, interacting with the class and making students think about the theory behind GIS

Nadine is great! She knows her stuff and as an added bonus actually knows how to teach the material.  Highly recommend her as a teacher, but also highly recommend never to take gis-unless it will help you in your career.

She is quite entertaining.  She is more concerned about doing the lectures well then breezing through them from lack of time.  The labs require ALOT of work, but she warns the class in the very first lecture of this.
No complaints about her personally.  Her labs are verrrry long. 8-12 hours for 5% and she has pretty high expectations but otherwise very friendly (contrary to other reports) and helpful.

Made me care about GIS when I went into the class thinking it was something I had to do for REM. Clearly passionate with funny moments in lectures, and really cared about students' success. Only thing is the final had a question that wasn't covered in lectures or labs. Also don't buy the lab textbook, I never had to use it.

Best teacher I've had at SFU thus far. Lectures were engaging with funny moments, and he made me care about GIS when I went into the class looking at it as something I needed to do for REM. Only thing is the final had a question worth a large amount of points that we didn't cover at all during class or labs.

unclear instructions for assignments 
doesn't explain difficult concepts well
disrespectful to some students

Like his other classes there are very few assignments but there is a good amount of content for each week for the student to learn. He cares about the class and wants people to succeed in this class. If you know gis stuff then you should be fine. For the exams, focus on key concepts.
He is one of the most exceptional professors I've encountered at sfu and serves as an excellent guide for those looking to enter the GIS field.

This is hands down the worst prof I've ever had. Doesn't matter if you study or attend all of the lectures he will still put things on an exam he has actually NEVER taught you! Make sure you remember everything you've ever learned in high school because those things are tested even though he never once goes over any of it with you. He is the worst!

Lectures are dry and not immediately meaningful coming from someone who hasn't used GIS before and doesn't care much about compsci but he set up the course in a way that there was a lot of fun hands-on stuff and he was very nice and conversational whenever he wasn't in Lecture Mode
Shiv was a great prof. Very caring and wants the class to succeed. Course felt a bit heavy with lab and lecture material but it is doable if you put the effort in.

Professor Balram is a great lecturer, and is generally pretty good at teaching the course concepts. There are lots of assignments, but they aren't too hard, and you're given plenty of time for the final project. Most of the difficulty rating comes from the final exam, which was fairly brutal (at least for me). Overall, pretty good prof!

He is a good teacher. His lecture doesn't contain enough info so you MUST go to class and take note carefully or you won't pass. First assignment is easy but later assignments, project he marks much harder. TA is helpful, not the grader. Intersession make it pretty rush. Final is brutal, you need to learn and adapt but not some definition question.

Shiv was probably one of the best professors I've taken at SFU. He cares about his students and is very clear and concise about what he's looking for. Modules were organized and notes were very useful. Attend all the lectures and the assignments were also straightforward. Final was hard so make sure to study in advance.

Shiv is a hilarious prof (sometimes no one understands his jokes lol). He does a good job of showing practical applications of GIS and explaining concepts but is sometimes vague when asking questions. He's also kinda picky about answers and his final was pretty hard. Shoutout to TA Shuoge for marking my hw mercifully enough to get an A. 10/10 prof

Awesome and very funny prof! The only problem I found was that even though the assignments were pretty straight forward and easy, the questions at the end were hardly covered in class. The final is a bit brutal though so don't study last minute for it. Everything is online but it's explained better in class.
Work hard on the assignments and project and you could end up with a B- before the final. Final was hard. I got 20/30 and ended up with a B+. Best Prof ever.

Awesome Prof. But the finals was brutal. After all the interactive lectures which were the best I have ever had and all those concepts learned in class I thought finals wouldnt be bad. But everything learned in class wont be enough as you need to study really hard for his finals. Overall best prof ever. Would love to take another class with him.

Shiv is a great prof and you can tell he is a really smart guy. The questions he asks in class require you to think and it gets the class engaged. I think this is his best quality. He also has a good sense of humour. I would recommend taking his class if you have the chance.

Shiv is an excellent professor. He has a great sense of humour, which makes it easy to pay attention. More importantly, he engages the class with questions that make you think about the material you need to understand. His teaching style is rare, so I would definitely recommend taking his class. Gain easy marks in lab projects, exam is tough. .
As long as you do well in your assignments and final project you can still pass the course with a B if you didnt do well on the final exam.

My only regret was not taking this course earlier!! Over my many years of uni he is hands down in the top!! Excellent prof that keeps you engaged, entertained and you learn a thing or two as well. Tough to find ppl like Shiv nowadays *gasp

This is hands down the best course I have taken at SFU and so glad I took it with only one more semester before I graduate! Shiv is an excellent prof and very considerate too. Great ability to recall examples on the fly and relate them to the lecture concepts - the cost distance analysis and alligators example was hilarious!! Super positive dude!

The course was intensive, but Shiv did a masterful job with explaining and pacing the content. The TA was super too. I came in with no Q experience but Shiv was always willing to answer my questions at office hours. I got A-! Thank you Shiv and have a great summer break.
A wonderful and caring prof. I really enjoyed this course, everything was so organized. I will definitely take more courses with him in Fall.

Superb course! Well organized notes and assignments. I graduated in Summer but took this course to give me an edge in the job market. Shiv is the best prof I encountered while at SFU. I now wish I had taken the SIS Certificate.
Shiv is the most hilarious prof, i love him. Everyone should take a class with him!

I took the summer session one (6 weeks condensed course)...people complained about having not enough time to finish the final term project which is totally bs. I finished my project in one night (6 hours) and got 100%...Shiv is a nice guy, though I don't really get his humor in class...He gives high mark on assignments but watch out for the final
I thoroughly enjoyed the lectures. Shiv is easy going guy and funny as hell. Awesome lecturer too. I am now going to take more GIS course for sure.
One of the most rewarding courses I have taken so far at SFU. Shiv was always very helpful when I had questions. Super prof and person!
Excellent Prof and mentor. He took the time to write a reference letter for me and give me good tips on answering job interview questions. I got the co-op job. You are awesome Shiv!
Really enjoyable course. Lots of practical examples and videos. It was nice to see how GIS can be applied in the real world. Take any courses with this Prof, he is very good!
Amazing prof!
Very well organized and convincing teacher. I took geog 251 with him this semester too. I learned a lot.

Nice guy, seems serious at the beginning of every class, but is actually quite funny and enjoys students' humour. Has fair expectations from students, no mt, but DO attend as many lectures possible, slides won't have everything he talks about - those will be the most important concepts!
This is my first GIS course. I really enjoyed it. May even switch majors in Fall. The teacher is very good, take any courses you can with him you will learn a lot.
